title: Man with knee condition forced to walk 6 miles home from hospital after heart scare
text:

A hospital patient with a debilitating knee condition was forced to walk six miles home after being discharged in the early hours of the morning.

Paul Lee, 55, was rushed to Forth Valley Royal Hospital suffering from a suspected heart attack on October 2.

After hours of tests at the hospital, doctors concluded he wasn't having a heart attack and could return home, the Daily Record reports .

He claimed despite it being almost 1am he wasn't offered any transport to take him home and said he had no money for a taxi or public transport, and no-one to ask for a lift.

(Image: Daily Record)

Mr Lee, who suffers with mobility problems after having re-constructive surgery on his knee 17 years ago, claims a doctor told him he'd have to walk and he decided to make the agonising six-mile journey on foot.

He said it took him three-and-a-half hours and he wasn't home until 4.45am.

Mr Lee claimed he had been provided with transport home from hospital in past.

He said: "I've always been given a taxi home.

"They told me I could wait for the buses to come on at 6am but that was a five hour wait and I didn't have any money to pay for the bus.

"A doctor told me I'd have to walk.

"I suffer with mobility problems. I had reconstruction on my left knee and my right knee was shattered.

(Image: Daily Record WS)

"I have had multiple walking problems since.

"A couple of miles from the house I felt like lying down and dying."

Mr Lee says his knees were injured when he was knocked down and attacked in 2002 and claims he suffered a brain injury in the incident and still feels affects from that.

He also believes his recent heart attack and angina means he should have met the criteria for transport home.

A spokesperson for NHS Forth Valley said: "Like most hospitals in Scotland we do not routinely provide transport for patients attending our emergency department.

"We do have a freephone taxi booking service and the majority of local taxi firms are happy to take patients home and then arrange payment.

"The Scottish Ambulance Service also provides a patient transport service for individuals who meet the medical criteria for this service.

"We are sorry if these options were not discussed with the patient before they left the hospital and we would encourage them to contact our Patient Relations Department so that they can look into what happened and identify any changes or improvements, if required."
description: Paul Lee said he felt like "lying down and dying" a couple of miles from his house in Falkirk, Scotland
